description.text:
I needed a way to set my Foredom 44T handpiece up and out of my way when I wasn't using it. I didn't see any good solutions out there, and I figured I should just make one. I'm including the SCAD file as well so you can optimize it with your tastes. As it is attached to my workbench, it has a small (~ 1/8" wide) piece of neoprene CA glued to the fluted area to allow for a nice, soft set down of the handpiece into the cradle. The handpiece intentionally has a little bit of play in the cradle to minimize stress on the wrap-around areas. The first version was tighter, but the side cracked over time. There are two recessed screw holes (#8 machine screws) to hold the cradle to your desired mount position. Also, FYI, the handpiece cannot fall straight out, you must lift the handpiece up above the top lip in order to remove it, but you probably already assumed that. :) I like the feel of this piece now. However, the whole drawing is parametric to assist you in modifying a cradle for this handpiece, or perhaps even creating one for others. As I upload it, it's only my second iteration, but it works great for me. Enjoy!
Phil

I sketched up the eyepiece, making it slightly larger inside diameter but with break in hoop to allow a M3 wing nut and bolt (plus washer) to be used to clamp the attachment on.
This makes the exact diameter of eyepiece it is fitted to less critical and also allows the hoop to be opened up slightly wider during fitting to clear any sightly wider parts due to rubber eyepiece mouldings.
Depending on scope diameter it may be possible to put a grip tape on inside of hoop for better grip if required to pad it out.

title: Roller Ball Bearing Filament Spool Insert

description.text:
This is a Customizable Filament Spool insert for use with Roller Ball Bearings.
This should be able to be used with any size roller ball bearing, as long as the roller bearing is smaller than the hole in the filament spool. The idea is to use this with a threaded rod. I use nuts on one side and a spring clip on the other side to allow for quickly changing spools. The spacer allows the ball bearings to be separated from the nuts/spring clip attached to the threaded rod. Numerous prints were done using this 8x22x7 ball bearing. This ball bearing works well with an 8mm (5/16") threaded rod:
608ZZ 8x22x7 Shielded Greased Miniature Ball Bearings
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBD6X4 (The pictures show the rod sitting on thing:761893.) Tony Hansen 2015

title: Frosty: Thin Mini-ITX case for Asus H81T

description.text:
Minimalistic, compact and fully equipped computer case for a mini-ITX motherboard. Specifically made for Asus H81T, but should work fine for many others as long as using external powerbrick or very compact PSU - Asus H81T has built in power socket that works fine with most Dell laptop chargers - no modification needed. Thoroughly ventilated - NO CASE FAN NEEDED.
With Intel stock CPU fan running in silent mode, with CPU on full load at 3.2Ghz, the computer is still almost dead silent and CPU temp rarely go above 40°C - idle temperature is around 30°C Has two slots for 2.5" drives (SSD or HDD). For extra safety you can add a dab of hot glue or double-sided tape under the drive(s) to secure them if you plan to move the computer around a lot. Standardized motherboard mounting holes fits all mini-ITX boards. Depending on your print settings and screws used, you might want to tap or drill up the mounting holes slightly. There is a big safety margin between the disks and motherboard, if you have an isolation layer to avoid shorts or plan to fasten disk(s) with hot glue, you can file/cut the mounts down several mm to get a drop of the entire motherboard. Snow flake hole centered directly on top of CPU fan. Intel Core i5 and Pentium stock coolers tested and fits height-wise, possibly others too. Has a socket for a standard PC power or reset switch that can be salvaged from almost any computer. Placed near the right rear corner. Mostly out of sight, yet easy to reach. Has a minimal hole for power LED in front, drill this up from the inside if too small when printed. Fasten LED with hot glue if needed. The the top part slides on from above, using guide rails. There is however no locking mechanism, so grabbing hold of the bottom part is recommended if you want to move the computer around. On the other hand, it's very easy to remove the top for troubleshooting and upgrading the hardware.
If you want a tighter fit for the guide rails, wrap some tape around them; even double-sided should work.

Since I printed in PLA, I sanded, then painted with acrylic clear coat for more shiny surface. If I were to print in ABS; I would do a carefully acetone vapor treatment.
Pictures coming.
Done from absolute scratch in TinkerCad.

comments.text: I'm taking on the challenge of freecad and my second project will be a thin mini itx case! (Basic box)
comments.author: I8igmac

comments.text: Hi l8igmac, I actually went without using the metal shield as it wouldn't really serve any purpose in this case, I recommend you do the same. See more photos on https://www.thingiverse.com/make:183530, images 5-6 in particular - Photo 6 is taken slightly from above, in real life the upper edge doesn't extend below the top edge of the ports. I have both HDMI, LAN, USB thumbdrive, USB sound card and Bluetooth dongle attached at the same time, they all fit through the rear slot. I had a look at the Asus N3050T, it should fit without problems. The rear ports does not extend higher than on my H81T, the mounting holes are identical (Mini-ITX standard). The top of the 4 posts is about 1mm above the lower edge of the rear slot, but I designed the posts so that you can easily sand them down to the height you want if needed. I really don't think it will be necessary, but it's nice to know the option exists. Good luck!
comments.author: I8igmac

comments.text:
I love the design, too bad it exceeds the 20 cms of your standard print bed... actually a safe size is 18cm, with 20cm or maybe even 19, using brim you get skipped steps outside of the boundaries...
Since you have the sources, do you think you can slim it down to minimal size by moving the borders inwards? I've printed another minimal case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1285560 remixed by me from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1006832 ) which is 18cm and fits snugly my D510MO, and it was barely printable inside my available bed.
comments.author: ephestione

comments.text: Hi, glad you like the design. Unfortunately, I can't slim it down much more since the corners are round and the motherboard would otherwise hit the edges. It might be possible to slim it down slightly, but that would take hours of work in the design tool I used (Tinkercad). I published it under CC Attribution license, so you are free to remix it if you want to give it a go.  I'm not sure there is a standard size printer, but it should print fine on a RigidBot (any version), Ultimaker (2+) and Lulzbot (TAZ5) to name a few.

description.text: Update (12/10/16) Some have asked me about where I found black epoxy. The truth is I didn't! I actually just added a few drops of Testors black model paint while mixing the two part epoxy. It works great! I haven't tried any other colors but I don't know why it wouldn't work as effective. Update (7/19/2016) I added a picture of the rear of the guitar body that shows the screws and socket head cap screw locations, plus the hardware, Note only one spring was used in this setup. Update (2/27/2016): Added bottom left component without initials in STL & SolidWorks (2016 format). This detail can then be printed w/o initials or use the SolidWorks file to create your own design on the face. This is a remix of Jon Stevenson's '62 Fender Stratocaster. He featured his progress on tumbler.com: http://3dprintedguitar.tumblr.com Jon's original files are found here: https://grabcad.com/library/snapfit-3d-printed-guitar-1 Jon was inspired by Jeff Campbell's Stratocaster model on GrabCad: https://grabcad.com/library/62-fender-stratocaster I have made adjustments to the files so they can be printed on a smaller format delta style printer. The six main parts of Jon's design have been turned into eight. I have removed the lizard and added my sons initials as this was a Christmas present for him.

There are other files but this is my first attempt at scanning the inside of my truck for a custom adapter to turn the stereo system into a touch enabled console like a Tesla.  Unfortunately I wasn't able to get the entire vehicle since I didn't have a garage but I have pictures of what the rig looked like.  There will be a youtube video explaining more about the hardware and what I was doing.
The pictures of the mesh are a before and after the software stitches them together.  This was done at low resolution on dark settings.  I took probably about 20 captures.  I could have done more if I had my desktop with me.  I was only using half of an acer Iconia with an i5 and it was having some issues.
So far I like the einscan-S.  Now I need to figure out how to do pcbs and this thing will be awesome to scan things with.

title: 1515 allen key z probe retract riser

description.text:
I needed a riser to hold the Z probe retract bolt after adding adjustable bed clamps to my printer. The bed rose about 30mm, so the effector could no longer reach the bolt to push the zprobe back in without the hot end hitting the bed. This lets you put the bolt at a higher level. requires: 2x M3x8 bolts and nuts for mounting
1 longer M3 bolt to act as the adjustable platform for the zprobe to retract against I made the holes too small initially, so had to ream them out with a drill to get the screws through. Tried to put a hole for an M3 nyloc nut, but the size was too small so I just screwed straight into the hole below. I adjusted the size in the scad file, but have not tried re-printing as it works fine with just the M3 bolt.

title: Character tower generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: You may input any text to generate your own tower. For example, π, root of 2, and so on. Of course, you may write a love letter and generate a tower for your lover. That might be a really special gift. :) The number of letters determines the height of the tower. The more you input, the higher it is. If you want to print it easily, set the inner_wall parameter to "YES". It will add an inner wall with the thickness of the half thickness value. When setting inner_wall to "NO", it's better to use numbers or uppercase letters. Just leave the bottom_symbol empty if you don't need the bottom symbol. Leave several blanks if you want all characters to be shown over the bottom. Using non English characters needs a correct font. If you want to do that, download the .scad source file and use OpenSCAD on your computer. You have to modify the source code of the tower_of_characters module according to the font you use. You may take a look at the tower_of_chinese_characters module for reference. Find things about PI.
Take a look at Text and cylinder.

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

I wanted a clip/latch which wouldn't make the job harder when removing the panels (by falling out of place). I looked on here but found nothing to my liking, so I created this latch.
Drilling a 1/4" hole through the panel (while making sure the hole is far enough over to allow the inside latch to clear the edge when turned) allows you to clip the two parts together. The outside knob should make contact with the outside wall so no matter which way it is turned (provided you drilled the hole correctly) it will stop the panel from going inwards making it easy to install the panels without overpassing the panel's position.
The two are connected via a square peg which allows the inside catch to be installed in any 1 of 4 positions available while keeping the image upright and the finger grips on the sides when "locked". The image on it right now is a wolf howling, but you can change it out for whatever you want.
It fits a wall thickness of 3/16". I used a piece of 1/8" plexiglass for the panel and they work great.

ReplicatorG
Skienforge (50)
Slicing Profile: Replicator 2 Slicing Defaults
(Infill_PerimeterOverlap(ratio): 0.3)

description.text:
Ultrascope is a 3D printed telescope project organized by openspaceagency.com.  They recently released the print files for the project, but several of the components are too large to print on a Replicator-sized print bed.  The OpenSCAD file included here, will split those components into smaller sections, and add alignment pins and sockets.  It also includes a pin and socket test file so you can adjust the fit.
From openspaceagency.com: "Ultrascope is an open-source robot telescope - or ARO (Automated Robotic Observatory) - controlled by a smartphone. It empowers citizen scientists with a low cost and open source robotic telescope to assist the work of professional astronomers."

Printer:

Replicator

Notes: Instructions for setting the parameters are located in the header of the OpenSCAD file. They allow you to select the component being split and whether you are printing the male or female half. There is also an option to add mouse ears (aka 'helper disks) to the split ends of the prints where they are likely to lift. You will first need to download the Ultrascope files from openspaceagency.com. Print settings for each part are listed under the 'process' tab at openspaceagency. OpenSCAD is a free download from openscad.org.
The Ultrascope image is from openspaceagency. I've only printed enough of it to know that the split files work.

This print is a useful tool in electromagnetic physics and generic mathematical cross products. The goal of the design is to prevent embarrassment by eliminating the right hand rule (sticking your hand in the air and bending your fingers). It is also a quick and easy way to determine final vector directions in any given cross product. Engraved on the model are the variables in two important electromagnetic equations. One is QVXB=F and the other is QVXR=B.

I like to take baths in my whirlpool tub time-to-time but have noticed tiny particulates in the bath water whether or not the jets were turned on.  Barring dirt and grime coming off from me, I've put the blame on the plumbing.
Since I don't use the jets, I've electrically unplugged the pump and decided on a temporary means to plug/unplug the jets.  This way I can unplug the jets after the bath to allow the jet plumbing to dry.  I didn't expect this design to be water tight.   It was basically so that there's no free flow in/out of the plumbing.
To my amazement, I had some difficulty finding plugs out there.  So to impress the wife, this design was born.  
This is my first Customizer thing and I hope it works for your sizes.
Disclaimer:  I take no responsibilities for injury to self or property.  :-)

remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Z-Axis Alignment Posts

remixed_from.author: TeamTEOR
remixed_from.title: WanHao Duplicator i3 Z-Axis Alignment Post Holder

description.text:
These are intended to work with printers that have an x-axis bar that moves up and own along a z-axis. If you get creative you may come up with another use for them. They are based on my previous posts I made for my Wanhao Duplicator i3 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1138928 I also borrowed the basic idea of TeamTEOR's holder for my original posts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1198375. I decided to build a customizer just to see how it is done. Consider this a work in progress but it 'should' work. :) Note:
If you have any ideas on additional features I could add, send me a message or add a comment and I'll see what I can do. UPDATE: 2016/03/22
Drastically shortened the height of the holder. UPDATE: 2016/03/11
Added 'wiggle_room' variable to make the holes in the holder slightly larger for easier fits. UPDATE: 2015/01/03
Added ability to make posts have a flat side like mtnrunner19's remix of my original posts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1201542

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Supports are only recommended if you print the holder as well. Otherwise any sane settings should work.

Print Them I highly recommend printing two posts as you will get more accurate results. Try to print them at the same point on the X Axis. Raise your Z Axis high enough to fit your posts under the X Axis bars on both sides. You should get them as far toward the the case as you can and still have the X Axis bar rest on them. Disable steppers and manually screw the Z Axis until both sides are touching your posts. If you are way out of alignment make sure to not screw one side further than the other as you may cause issues. Try keeping them level while lowering them onto the posts. Remove posts. Slide posts parallel to X Axis bar until you can remove them without bumping the bar up on accident. Now your Z Axis should be aligned. The Holder If you opted to print the holder, note that it prints upside down. I recommend installing it wherever you want with some double sided tape. I use Gorilla Tape. Assuming you flipped the holder 90 degrees, to place the posts in the holder, put the posts in upside down.

title: Traxxas Nitro Stampede 2x4 Battery Box Relocated

description.text:
Since throwing in an .18 sized glo engine (from Hobby King) on my Traxxas Nitro Stampede, it's been admittedly less fun as it is now too powerful to stay on all 4 wheels.
In attempt to move as much weight to the front of the truck as possible, I decided to move the rx battery box up.  I'm hoping the rx batteries don't ignite the fuel in event of a crash!
I've not yet had a chance to test this, but wanted to share it with others.

I didn't like the rod holders I found, so (as is often the case) I made my own. The STL here is for a 1.5 inch rod. My apologies; I forgot to switch to mm before exporting the STL.
I designed this to be completely parametric in Fusion 360, and included the f3d file so you can adjust the rod size. Just open the file, in the tool bar click Modify->Change Parameters. In the window that pops up you can change the User Parameter "rod_diameter" to whatever diameter you like. It should work down to a 1 inch, or so, rod.

Headphones are incredibly ubiquitous. They can range from different sizes to styles, comfort to noise canceling and now even wireless bluetooth. Here's an upgrade you won't find on even the biggest brands. RGB NeoPixel LEDs. This DIY upgrade uses NeoPixel LED rings and an Adafruit Feather Bluefruit LE module to make slick lighting effects. With The Adafruit Bluefruit LE connect app for iOS or Android, you can change the colors of the LEDs using a color picker and even trigger dope animations with the tap of a button. The 3D printed enclosures keep everything together and doesn't add too much weight or bulk to your pair of headphones. Read the full learning guide for a full step by step tutorial

description.text: Thingiverse is cool

This is a universal spool hub/holder designed to make spool change-outs quick and easy.
  • Three "bolt" lengths available: Original, Large, Extra Large
  • Accommodates spools with a center hole of 50mm - 65mm
  • Other sizes available using parametric Fusion 360 file included
  • Can be used with or without 608 bearings
  • Designed with printability in mind - no supports required
    • Changing the spool is a breeze as it is essentially a giant nut and bolt with cone-like faces, and the nut threads on very quickly due to the coarse thread pitch. Once the hub is mounted on the spool simply slide in a piece of 5/16" rod. You can optionally pre-load the bearings by threading a lock-nut on either side of the "bolt" to adjust the amount of free-wheeling during a print. Although the included .stl files will accommodate spools with a center hole of 50mm - 65mm, I've also included a parameterized Fusion 360 file so you can tweak the dimensions and lengths as required, or customize the bearing / axle tolerances etc. The minimum size that can be accommodated is 40mm due to the size of the bearing and threads. This thing was inspired by the cone-like hubs such as: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767317 and the bearing insert design is from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:605360 which lets you extract the bearing if required. Update 2016-11-24:
    Version 2.0 now available. Added a chamfer to the threads on both the nut and bolt to make them easier to engage. (Using the method described here). Update 2017-12-04:
    Large and Extra Large "bolt" lengths now available!
  • Original for spools up to 75mm wide (print height 105mm)
  • Large up to 110mm (print height 140mm)
  • Extra Large up to 140mm. (print height 170mm)

RepRap

comments.text: Awesome,
comments.author: EnKaye

comments.text:
Just printed, but when putting the bearings, I was wondering if the 8mm center hole wouldn't introduce some friction with the rod?
Indeed, when used with a bearing, the load of the spool should be applied to the outer ring of the bearing through the holder, and thus, the rod should be in contact only with the inner ring of the bearing and especially not with the holder.
comments.author: Kachidoki

comments.text: There should be no problem using a 5/16" rod.  I actually didn't consider using an 8mm rod - I believe there should be enough clearance for that too, but if not I'd love to hear any feedback you have and I can update the model if it needs more wiggle room.
comments.author: Kachidoki

comments.text: Well, I did some tests. When no spool is loaded, surprisingly the holder spin much well without the bearings (the grease introduce more friction), but it is also alot noiser. When loaded with a brand new 750g filament spool (which wheight approx. 1kg with the spool itself), the bearing version spin much well. Maybe too much, that can lead to an unwanted unroll (especially when retracts occurs) and filament tangling outside the spool. I think I prefer to use it without bearings, the performance is enough for the normal use-case.
comments.author: Foreverwinter

comments.text: Any suggestions to get the threaded area to print cleaner?  I'm getting some stringing and wobbliness in the threads. I'm printing in PLA at 60mm/s.  It's just the threaded areas, everything else prints nice and clean.  I'm printing the bolt right now in hopes of just screwing them together to kind of clean it out, but figured I's ask.
comments.author: sonnaps

comments.text: The bolt usually prints cleaner than the nut which sometimes gets the "stringing" you mentioned.  I usually clean up any bad strings with some cutters and just screw them together a few times to clean up any other imperfections.  The threads have plenty of play in them (until they're tightened against the spool), so imperfections shouldn't affect the performance.

description.text:
Dieses Projekt ist nur enstanden, weil kein vergleichbares druckbares Gehäuse für ein Raspberry Media Center vorhanden ist. Oder ich habs nicht gefunden. Was solls.
Dieses Gehäuse funktioniert für ein RPi 1 B und RPi 2 B. Es besitzt zusätzliche Ausnehmungen für optionale Schnitstellen. (USB-Hub, CardReader, LCD, RJ45, ...).
Zusätzlich ist auch eine Ansteuerlogik (Platine) integriert, welche das Display, den Lüfter und die LED beim Einschalten des RPis aktiviert bzw. beim Abschalten deaktiviert. Schaltplan und PCB sind im Archiv vorhanden. Benötigte Teile (Datei im RAR-File vorhanden): 1xRPi 1 Model B oder RPi 2 Model B
1xPower-Schalter (Wippenschalter Netzschalter 230V 3A // H=19mm, B=19mm)
1xStromanschluss (Buchse rund H=11mm, B=9mm)
1xUSB-Hub 7fach (D-Link DUB-H7 (USB2.O) HUB USB 7P TxUSB-A{B} // Platine)
1xStromkabel + Adapter USB-Hub (D-Link DUB-H7 (USB2.O) HUB USB 7P TxUSB-A{B})
1xUSB-Kabel für USB-Hub (USB 2.0-Kabel A-Stecker auf B-Stecker)
1x LCD HD44780 (VIKAY VK2020, Datenblatt liegt bei)
1xTaster (rund D=15mm, silber)
1xSD-CardReader Extension (lt. Foto // B=29.4 max, H=4,4 max)
1xUSB-IR Reciever (Hama MCE Remote Control PC-Fernbedienung)
1xLAN-Adapter (InLine Cat.5e Patchkabelkupplung 2x RJ45 Buchse // H=23mm, B=17mm, T=38mm)
1xNetzwerkkabel (CAT5e Patch, min. 10cm)
1xCardReader (Transcend All-in-1, TS-RDF8K, uSB 3.0)
1xCardReader USB-Kabel (Transcend All-in-1, TS-RDF8K, uSB 3.0)
1xLochrasterplatine + (7x2Pin Klemme, 1x3Pin Klemme, 1x5V-Relay, 1xDrehpotentiometer <=10k für LCD Kontrast, 1x Transistor BC547B, Widerstand 1x6,8k Ohm, Widerstand 1x 0-100 Ohm bzw. Drehpotentiometer (0-100 Ohm) für Lüfterdrehzahl, wenn nötig (in meinem Fall nicht verbaut) --> INFO: Sollte ein zu starker Lüfter verbaut sein (zu viel Leistung (Ampere)) funktioniert die LCD Beleuchtung und die LED nicht mehr.
1xLED (5V, D=5mm)
14x20cm Steckbrückenkabel (Arduino, female-female, min 10cm)
Lüfter (5V, 40x40x11mm, XINDAFAN XD4010DC) Zusätzlich ist noch auf dem Deckel Platz für ein DVD/BD-Laufwerk (ohne Montagelöcher, -befestigungen, ...):
ich habe --> 1xSamsung SE-506BB/TSBD externer Blu-ray 6x Brenner Es sind alle Ausnehmungen im Gehäuse mit zusätzlichem "Stützblechen" (weis kein anderes Wort) versehen, es ist also kein Support notwendig während dem Drucken. Diese können dann nach belieben "rausgebrochen" werden. Am besten gehts mit nem kleinem flachen Schraubenzieher und nem Hammer. Bei mir hats funktioniert. INFO: Alle Bauteile müssen zu Montage nur verschraubt oder gesteckt werde. Bis auf Stromanschlussbuchse und SD-Card Extension (Rpi Betriebssystem) sind zu kleben. Sollte es beim Gehäuse Verbesserungsvorschläge oder Probleme geben bitte melden. Danke und viel Spaß CHANGELOG: 03.01.16 --> 1.Release & 1.Upload
03.01.16 --> Teileliste --> Widerstand/Drehpotentiometer für Lüfter korrigiert --> Sorry
03.01.16 --> Schaltplan, PCB-Layout (vereinfacht) erweitert und korrigiert, RAR-Archiv
neu hochgeladen, Teileiste zusätzlich hochgeladen
03.01.16 --> PCB-Layout mit TARGET 3001 V18 discover hochgeladen, RAR-Archiv
neu hochgeladen
08.01.16 --> Widerstand für Lüfter XINDAFAN max 30 Ohm. Optimal 10-18 Ohm.

Prusa i3 // AURORA Z605 + RAMPS 1.4

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Slic3r 1.1.7 // Layerhöhe = 0,3mm // Gehäuseunterteil = 3DPrima PLA schwarz 1.75mm // Deckel = 3DPrima PLA Luminous green

Modelliert mit Pro Engineer Wildfire 5.0 Das ganze Projekt wurde mit der Software von PTC eigens konstruiert. Wer Interesse hat kann seine eigenen Ideen oder Wünsche einbringen. Falls gröbere Änderungen von eurer Seite notwendig sind kann ich das Projekt gern umkonstruieren. Konvertierungen in andere Formate als die bereits vorhandenen nehme ich eigentlich nicht vor, wer trotzdemden Drang hat soll mich einfach mal anschreiben.

title: mazo case for amazon kindle voyage

description.text: Nookify your kindle voyage reader with the mazo case/grip. I like my kindle voyage but it's so thin it's a little hard to hold with one hand sometimes, especially when i'm trying to hold it more upright. I always liked the design of the nook with glowlight and the way the back curved in and made it easier to hold, but I'm firmly entrenched in the kindle ecosystem. I designed this case to make it a little easier to hold and use the voyage with one hand in the portrait orientation..

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15

Finishing and Assembly I sanded the whole thing lightly with 150 grit sandpaper to smooth it out and remove the burrs left by my printer. it gives the black PLA a worn grey appearance. I was going to paint it with some flexseal or something, but I actually like the feel as is. Feels a little like paper. uses 2 m3 15mm socket cap screws and nuts. The nuts go into the slots in the top piece and the screws thread up from the bottom. Depending on the quality of your printer, you may have some burrs or strings in the tunnel for the screws. I used a drill to clear them and make sure the screws would go all the way in before I started the assembly. For the case I printed (b1), the USB port opening was too small and I had to dremel the opening a little. I enlarged it on the model I'm uploading, but I've never printed this one (b2) so it might still be a bit small. If anyone prints this, let me know. I know the hole for the power button is not perfectly aligned, but it works and I don't want to waste the PLA and 4.5 hrs to print another one. before I used to put my pinky finger under the reader to support it insert the m3 nuts and push them in until they align with the holes. test the alignment with the 15mm m3 screws. after the case is on I can hold it without using my pinky. maybe a wider grip would be even better, but I'm going with this for now.

Simple Center Finder I made this to find the centre of a circle, particularly for me to align gears & wheels. The groove makes it easy to draw a line with a sharpie/marker. Simply align the inner edge of the tool to the outer edge of your circle/gear and draw a line. Repeat this once or more times and where the line crosses, that would be the center. I made two version. one at 90 degree and one at 110 degree angle. If you print it at thicker layers, no support is needed. Check out my other designs! Click on my profile. www.KikiTayBlog.com

title: Flash foot protector for Sony flashes

description.text:
The Sony multi-interface flash shoe is complex and delicate. It turns out the foot on flashes and flash controllers is typically plastic - and if you drop the item it breaks. This can be both inconvenient (equipment unexpectedly out of action) and expensive...
This tiny foot protector clicks on to your equipment and locks there - the usual device release button works as you expect. The images show the protector with a Nissin Air 1 flash controller. Files updated to a slightly more elegant shell...

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: There is a fill STL for a dissolvable filament support. You may be able to print this without fill by turning the STL upside down - but the best results for the small flange that clips the protector to the flash/controller will come with a dual material print. I use Simplify3D as the slicer - it is far superior to the Makerbot software...

author: KikiTay

description.text:
---Not finished but functional--- Project was an exercise in 123D for me & to test what kind of detail I could get without doing a 3-day print. These three files already put my printer to work for a little over 24hrs on a medium resolution. Remix or Glitch's 3pc Millennium Falcon & Adafruit Raspberry PI 2 case. Chose this model for ease of manipulation, and the reduced detail kept my 123D Design from crashing, as some of the more detailed models did. I chose the adafruit case because it was simple, but later added about 1mm to the bottom an side of base to re-enforce and create some ventilation and design features. I included some of my 123D files including one with and uncut top and unmodified base in case you want to remix from there... This is my first attempt at creating and printing something functional. So constructive comments are appreciated. I had to slice the top in half as it was too large for my M3D print bed. I customized the base to improve cooling and rigidity for print & added random details. Future refinements might include some way to lock the top halves together. Things I know could be improved:
1) Locking mechanism for top halves
2) Increase Clearance for HDMI molding near Falcon side round feature.
3) Improve text
4) Tubes for light pipes added to the front of the cockpit intended for some large monofilament or clear PLA to be used as light pipe to the PI's 2 on board LEDs I would have liked to make this considerably larger so all cables could exit the rear but I'm limited by my print bed.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium

Notes: I don't like the cylinders for the screws, I think they could use some more support and be drawn in as it's own support as a removable piece to reduce build time & material

123d I imported all the files I downloaded from Glitch and Adafruit into 123d Design (Ihad to use meshimizer to clean up some of the falcon after I scaled and stretched it. I duplicated and modified parts of the PI case to use as tools to model and align Glitch's Falcon. I then merged them and sliced the top in half to fit my print bed. Sounds simple, but it was a great learning exercise for 123D Design and getting use to solids and meshes and how to work around combining aligning the 2 when some features only work on solids.
test

CTF-Face - Unreal Tournament '99
Use support structure to baseplate and a brim. Layerheight and printspeed as low as you like it to achieve the best results.
I used layerheight 0.2, 50mm/s speed and 20% fill density, which took about 8 hours on my Ultimaker 2. Decreasing the layerheight to like 0.1 or even 0.06 would make the result a lot smoother but doubles the printtime.

Wanted to get a longer runtime on our baby monitor so I built a battery pack that'll hold one (1) 18650 sized Li-Ion battery. This meets the needs of a very small segment of the population, one who purchased an AngelCare baby monitor, model AC1100, is not satisfied with runtime and owns a 3D printer :) enjoy. Build instructions:
  • Print all parts in STL (pack, cap for 18650, and latch for bottom of pack)
  • Glue latch to bottom center of pack, let dry.
  • Drill holes for wiring.
  • Add in TP4056 Lithium Ion charger
  • Solder everything up and glue on cap.
    • Video here: https://youtu.be/waPYTC6LEK4

title: Stamp box for COLOP printer Q17

description.text:
Our family does a lot of geocaching. We started out writing (with pen or pencil) our geocache name in the logbook.
After a while I bought a stamp (with our 'logo' qbi2 on it) to sign the logbooks.
The box I bought it in started out as the box on the left of the photo (sized to the stamp of course, but I only had the box of another stamp available for the photo now). After a while the box was in such a bad shape, I had to duct tape it (as seen on the photo).
Still this was not a perfect solution, as the inside of te box still deteriorates over time.
Now with my new 3d printer, I decided to create a plastic box for it.
This is the result :-) I've uploaded 2 versions of the box. One with our geocache logo on the front and in the bottom and one 'plain' box (no logo's). I printed my box with wood filament, which gives it a nice tough.
I have yet to use it in the field.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3 (clone)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%
I used Coreldraw X3 for the logo and freecad to create the box and add the logo.

title: Enclosure for raspberry and power supply

description.text: An enclosure the fits a Raspberry Pi 1B and a power supply for it (like this one: http://www.ebay.com/itm/EU-Plug-White-For-Samsung-Galaxy-S4-Micro-USB-Data-Cable-Home-MGAC-Wall-Charger-/231625043146?hash=item35ededacca:g:jd8AAOSwHnFVqKuG). My dogs had fitbit zips for christmas. For those of you who don't know the fitbit concept, it consists of a range of different performance trackers and a social media where you can share your achievements with your friends. The zips that I gave my dogs are just a pedometer. To sync the individual trackers with the webside you either use a phone or conputer with bluetooth. The problem is then, that you have to log in as all the individual users in other to sync everyone of the tracker... that is really anoying and take so much time. Luckily there is an opensource project that allows you to sync any tracker in range (https://bitbucket.org/benallard/galileo). I installed galileo on a rpi with an attached motion sensor (from now on refered to as "the sync station"), and placed it next to the dogs water bowls. This way, everytime the dogs goes to the water bowl, their trackers will automatically be synced, and I (being friend with my dogs) can see how much they have walked and thereby see if they need more for dinner. Though this design has been made for a very specific purpose, I reckon that theenclosure can be used for many different application. Therefore I have also uploaded a lid for the enclosure without the pir sensor.

comments.text: This is perfect! I have a totally different use case but want to have an RPI plugged in our living room and was looking for something "all in one" to basically just plug it in and forget it. Being in a living space I wanted it as low profile as possible. I'll need to modify the design a bit since I'm in the US and need that style plug-in. I'll remix and post an updated file once I get around to doing it. Thanks for sharing.
comments.author: robweber

comments.text: I like the idea and might buy a few fitbit zips though i have no dogs yet. Good job!

comments.text: Ohh no, that's a big problem - you surely need to have a dog :)

Hey!

Let us know if you need any more help!

title: PROTOTYPE OF COLONIAL STYLE CENTER TABLE

description.text: This table, with some colonial style, has two sliding doors on both sides and a glass top on top, resting on four metal tubes fixed to the structure of the mobile timber. This is supported by two bases, which in turn rests on the floor. Suggested materials for the manufacture of furniture in its real dimensions are wood, and the basis for the structure, beyond the doors, glass for the top, and metal pipes to support the lid. For the installation of two ports, it is necessary to use hinges and clasps, which may be of metal.

For 3D printing, just download the file in STL. A prototype miniature level, I find it easier to print once the whole, with the exception of the doors, which can be put together using the scotch tape to type emulates latch and hinge. Also disponibilizei the file in 3ds format.

description.text:
I wanted to adjust the height of my coilovers, and, i have no spanners. BUT, i do have a 3d printer!
And so the designing began. I havent actually tried to adjust the height, and i have doubt they will be strong enough to wind the collar up, but down shouldnt be a problem (i have been using a monkey wrench, and its quite hard with that even (winding up that is, the car does weigh 1800kg though))
but for someone with a light car, this might work, and, if u do your own aluminium casting, you can cast this in ally and have a very strong c-spanner!
i may upload a couple different sizes if this version is too small for the height adjusting collar, but it is a good size for the locking collar on my tanabe sustec pro coilovers.

Printer:

CTC dual extruder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

60%

Notes: used linear infill in makerbot desktop 3.8 the raft is there to help stop warping due to its length, would also recommend not using cooling fan. used 3 shells for added strength, can go higher if u find it isnt strong enough still.

comments.text: I was thinking about making one for my bike Fox shock... any clue the dimensions? Do you have the cad file for editing and willing to share?
comments.author: sshawn

comments.text: dont have it anymore sorry mate, its scaled in mm. 201.67 x 53.98 x 8mm overall dimensions
comments.author: sshawn

comments.text: for anyone reading, my spanners broke whilst attempting to adjust my coilies, worked well on the rears, but the front with the extra spring rate broke the tip off, a few extra shells would probably work, but ally casting would be the way.

title: GoPro 25° tilted strap on for quadcopter batteries

description.text:
I was asked if i could design a tilted gopro mount that should be fixed itself on a quadcopter battery.
This might be needed on the 180mm race quadcopters, where just not enough space is available to fit battery, gopro, antenna, ... The 30mm wide base fits perfectly on turnigy multistar 1400 4s race spec batteries. Usage:
  • Put some anti slip sheet below gopro and the foot.
  • Use the soft fix straps to fix the gopro and the whole holder on the battery.
  • Then mount the battery as normal.

author: BetineMR

title: Porsche 911 LED Brake and 3rd Brake Board Frames and Clips

description.text:
These clips are used to secure the Spokeworks LED boards in a Porsche 911 Rear brake and 3rd Brake Fixtures.
Fits model years 1969-1989.
The 3rd brake frames fit periscope/snorkel and inside window-mount fixtures. 
The inside window-mount frames must be a Right and Left pair. Only the Right side frame is attached. The Left side frame can be realized in the slicer program by mirroring the right side.
The inside window-mount frames also must be positioned to sit flat on the platter. The bottom edge is flat but at a slight angle.
These clips must be made with ABS or other material with as high or higher temperature tolerance. PLA is not a good fit for this application.

Card tray for Zombicide, to store your cards. The box has four slots which each hold at least 54 sleeved cards. The lid is a tight fit, so it won't come of directly, but for transportation I would recommend using magnets to keep the lid in place (see 'post-printing') or use a rubberband. 
This is a fan made object to enhance the game, not trying to infringe copyrights.

I used black PLA for the box and the lid. When the print was finished I used sanding paper to give the logo a nice grey look that stands out from the black background. If you want to make sure the lid won't come off during transportation; the lid is attached to the box by small magnets. The holes are already in the print.
Box: cylindrical magnets with a diameter of 3mm and a length of 3mm.
Lid: square magnets of 3x3mm. Height 1mm.
Make sure the magnet fits by removing excess plastic, a drop of super glue and ready. (Mind the polarity).

title: GHOST PARADE, a tribute to Gzumwalt and Ruby Bot

description.text:
Inspired by Gzumwalt’s carousel (Thingiverse 515168) and Ruby Bot’s ghost emoij (Thingiverse 515168 https://youtu.be/KSgNyh706r0), I started working on a toy that brings the two together. Kids really love ghosts that glow in the dark, especially when they are dancing. https://youtu.be/tKu7NXdFd6s
The carousel has a motor base, which houses a small geared motor (AliExpress, also available with a 3mm shaft) and two or more cylindrical neodymium magnets, DxL=4x24 [mm].
The rotating platform is directly mounted to the motor shaft and carries five ghosts (printed at 50% of the actual size), fixed to the cylinder with a joint which houses an M3 bold and a small cubical neodymium magnet 5x5x5 [mm]. The M3 bolts can rotate freely, while the magnets are glued to the joint and the back of the ghosts. Use sandpaper to roughen the surfaces to obtain proper adhesion. Make sure no glue goes into the M3 bolt area. Use a marked cylindrical magnet to determine the correct position of the cubical magnets before applying the adhesive. The easiest way is to apply a drop of adhesive only at the back of the ghost just before positioning the joint. The same marked magnet is used to determine the position of the cylindrical magnets before they are pushed into their positions. The attracted end should face downwards. A little drop of glue prevents them from being pulled out. Since the magnets can be accessed from the bottom as well, it is easy to bring them in the right position. Use the lowest voltage at which the motor runs smoothly. During each rotation, the ghosts are charged by a light source which illuminates the ghosts through the window at the backside of the motor unit.
Any light source like a simple torch can be used. I made a small panel with 42 white 3mm leds. These can be found on AliExpress at incredibly low prices. I bought a hundred of them for only US$1.37, free shipping! Put three of them in series with a 120 Ohm resistor and repeat that 14 times. Basically you just need two magnets, one at the back side to make sure the ghosts are aligned properly during charging and one at the front side to make them dance. Of course you are free to use the other positions as well. No roof? Why not put a wobbly ghost in the centre (Thingyverse 1064239) ? An intriguing design of muzz64. If you insist on a roof, there are two options included as STL-files..

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: To have a nice contrast between the glowing ghosts and their back ground, it is best to print the platform in black PLA. The ghosts are printed in green glow in the dark PLA. If your slicer allows it, print X and Y at 50% of the original size, but leave the thickness Z at 100%. In this way the 3D quality of the ghosts is much better. For the motor base, any color can be used. All items are printed with 0.2 layer thickness and 20% infill. No rafts or supports. All parts fit on a 10x10 cm bed.
To make it easy to adapt the magnet and motor shaft dimensions, the OpenSCAD files are attached as well.

description.text: A simple hair comb.

Update 7/15 Eliminate steps 3-5 by using a free-ware program called "img2cad".
This makes changing a jpeg to a 3D dxf very easy, Update 8/4/13 Zero Backlash worm gear / drive using the technique outlined in this project. Print files "spiral1 and spiral2" then "walk" the shaft through the gear with a parted vice and light hammer taps (a few times from both directions). I used a 100 grit sand paper to smooth the surfaces of the worm gear shaft and Mopar low resistance grease used for garage doors. It glides like magic with no backlash.

This video (see link) shows how I go about configuring custom spur, pinion gears, involute gears, ring, planetary, rack and pinion gears. See this instructional video: http://youtu.be/nF_XRl7uvr0 There are lots of ways to do this (most of them are probably much better) but here's my practical experience that I use for rapid prototyping of laboratory equipment with stepper motors, the Tamiya belt drive kit and the makerbeam connector set (see below). The same easy and fast method applies to making bevel / conical gears, making short worm drives and gear trains. Two of the images above show gears made with this process and have a gear ratio of 1.9:1 (17 teeth to 9 teeth). In the second I slurry welded the smaller gear onto the larger to make part of a gear train. For a worm drive just rotate the extruded top level by say 10 degrees and then keep extruding until you reach the desired number of turns. Procedure demonstrated in video:
1) use program Gear Template Maker (GTM) to configure gear
2) export from GTM to a jpg image file
3) import jpg image file into freeware Wintopo and vectorize
4) play around with parameters maybe give image a wider white boarder so the vectorizing is clear of boarders.
5) save vector from Wintopo as a 3D dxf file
6) import 3D dxf into a CAD program and extrude surfaces
7) save the extruded file from a CAD program to an stl file
8) you can clean in kisslicer or free netfab if needed
8) upload stl file into a 3D printer
9) print out the 3D gears
10) use gears as internal constructs or as part of belt drive system Helpfull sites: How gears work: http://science.howstuffworks.com/transport/engines-equipment/gear.htm See also link to makerbeam connectors for examples of how this can be used with stepper motors and the Tamiya belt drive kit:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28179

Watch the video and post any questions.  
Thanks!

donb (http://www.thingiverse.com/donb) sent me a message recently about the SuperFormula (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superformula) as it reminded him of my other surface/solids work. Recognizing the fun challenge, I thought I'd code it up. But, instead of starting right away with the SuperFormula, I thought I'd start with the SuperEllipse, which is very close, and a step along the way anyway. This thing is an implementation of the SuperEllipse formula in OpenScad. What good is a SuperEllipse? Well, it's actually a surface of revolution. With it you can define the ellipsoid, sphere, cylinder, cube/rectangle, and myriad other funky looking shapes that are somehwere in between these. It's great because from one formula you get all sorts of things. Just imagine if this were a primitive in OpenScad, as it is in things like PovRAY. At any rate, the basic formulas are there. The fun thing is, you can render a point cloud if you want. That is, only the vertices, represented as tiny little spheres. You can also render as a wireframe. That's nice because you can see the structure, on the outside and the inside as well. Lastly, you can render as a polyhedron. Perhaps the most cool of all is that you could render as all three, at the same time, by just changing the values of some parameters. The important file is superellipse.scad. With this one comes the 'superellipse()' module. This has parameters you can change to get the different shapes. Within the code, there is a reference to a page that gives examples with different parameters. By default, it renders with a radius of [1,1,1]. You can easily use the 'scale()' module to get a different size. Although the thing will generate 2-manifold objects, it seems to be extremely expensive to do CSG operations on them. UPDATE: I added another picture that shows a checkerboard pattern on it. That's a little bit of "precedural texture", which I haven't actually released as yet, but I thought it looked cool.

1) Download the two .scad files
2) Fiddle about with the various parameters to the superellipse() module
3) Look at the pretty pictures
4) Generate .stl for the ones you like
5) Print them out
6) Rejoice!

description.text: d

Problem with lost gas caps, you cannot get those little yellow gas caps and have to buy new cans, the special anti-spill nuzzles, tend to spray gas into the water when fueling boats, so we prefer to use the old style. Using stuffed rags plastic, tape and wine corks didn’t work for me, neither did leaving the cans open, so I designed this gas cap in blender from blender.org. It’s a free program, after tree attempts I made a design that seems to work for me. Printed with PLA plastic. PLA seems to resist gas and diesel well enough to work for our use. I seem to remember reading that PLA plastic can vent or interact with gas, but after using this for a year, I have not noticed it.

Mounting detials DO NOT drill out the 3mm mounting holes, they are undersized for a reason. This was designed for the screws to be screwed into place (locked). Screw them in until they just stop turning (snug), install the brackets and add the thumbscrews (nuts). This will keep the screws from spinning when adjusting your bed level. Although I use auto bed leveling I still like my bed as level as possible :)

Designed with Solidworks with easy removal/replacement in mind I love printing on glass, but never liked the binder clips or having anything protruding above the surface of the glass. So I designed these for my FT printer and the aforementioned glass. Yes, the button head screw are still above the surface but but not in the print area. I will however post a version with countersinks for those who want it. Otherwise they do exactly what I want, they keep the glass in place while printing yet allow me to quickly remove/replace it for cleaning. I have two of these pieces of glass and they are almost exactly the same size so they switch out perfectly (your mileage my vary ;-). If you need them tweeted for your glass/printer let me know, I'll do my best to help...

I was looking for a cupholder that I can use outside, and attach to my deck.  I didn't see one here, so naturally, I designed one!  
This holder can fit 12oz cans, bottles, and a "standard" pint glass (see pictures).  Use #8 x 1" flathead wood screws to secure it to whatever you like.  The mounting pad is sized such that the pint glass will not hit the mounting surface.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Custom-Built Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Used 0.4mm nozzle Does not need any supports, just print it, remove it, and use!

I designed this using SolidWorks 2016. The two driving factors on this were the size of the pint glass, the diameter of a 12oz can, and the can's height, so you can easily pick up the can when inside this holder. The diamond openings are just a little design flare along with a desire to reduce the overall amount of plastic. I also included openings to easily allow you to screw in the flathead screws. The CAD design was intended for #10 wood screws, but #8 wood screws are recessed better, so go with them! The holes are spaced 1.75" apart.
Enjoy!

Did you ever try to make a straight cut with this fancy little Dremel? I did and it was a total failure. So I came up with a guiding tool that actually worked and now I would like to share it with you. Fix your Dremel 225 Flex Shaft Attachment to this printed guide and now you can cut along the truck. Just remember to be careful and do not hurt yourself! Printed parts have no CE mark ;) The guide is big enough to fit a standard D38mm saw and even up to D44mm from some other manufacturers.
Theoretically with D38mm it should be possible to cut 5mm thick plate.
EDIT: "version 2" is now prepared - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1375735

Printer:

GATE 3novatica

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 works fine

Infill:

25% seems OK

Notes: All parts are designed to simplify printing. So no things like supports needed.
Trucks are in few different lengths - best would be to choose the longest one that fits in your printer.

Print few trucks to get desired length and connect them with dovetail wedges. Grind a little sliding surfaces to achieve one smooth truck. Take your time on that, the better it works with guide the safer and more precise will be your work. Notice that end of printed truck segments have rounded edges (printers fault) - eliminate them first. To make truck more rigid glue it together.
To fix Dremel 225 in guide you will need bolts and nuts. 4x M5 minimum 30mm long (better 35mm). Tighten bolts just by hand - Dremel has rubber coating so it is fixed firmly without a risk of damaging of plastic guide.
EDIT: "version 2" is now being prepared - see Remixs!

comments.text: Nifty! My suggestion would be to make the truck guide fit a standard piece of dimensional hardwood or an aluminum pipe. For ridigity and a true straight edge without fiddling with sanding and possibly gluing plastic pieces. Nice job over all!

description.text:
As the ballroom season has begun, its time to upgrade the cufflinks for my smoking. 
This project makes use of Adafruit sewable Neopixel embedded in the cufflinks made from transparent PLA. I used an Adafruit Gemma to control that Neopixel but of course there is a variety of boards to choose from.
The cap and pin didnt need a glue (yet), they are that tight that i squeezed them with pliers together.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I printed the cap with the opening downside. this has the tradeoff that it needs support, but the more important benefit that the outside is printed cleanly. Also the shell is able to withstand the squeezed-in pin in that setting. the supports on the inside could easily be removed with a thin plier and the result was surprisingly clean. The pin is best printed 90 degrees sideways, so that the PLA threads provide maximum robustness for the 3mm pin. It doesnt need lots of supports for that. I used the setting do generate supports only for 85 degrees or more, and all breakable.

I'v succeeded to print with little ukulele and It was good enough. But I'm not sure on bigger ones. Sorry for lack of documentation.

I have to say that this project is failed. I had printed it with standard PLA and 60% of infill. 1 year later, it's neck is bent(strings are floating almost a inch at the center), and I have no way to fix it. Furthermore, tuning gears are all broken. See the last updated pictures.
You can try stiffer materials, but I don't think current dimensions are feasible for FDM printers. I'm thinking about my next attempt to make a novel method to tune strings, and use aluminum extrusion as guitar body, someday..

A lightsaber I designed in Tinkercad for fun. I hope you enjoy making it as much as I enjoyed designing it. I recommend scaling down to around 0.9 of the original size. There is an open, empty crystal chamber and I purposely made it hollow for people to add whatever they wanted, including a blade, to make it as realistic as possible. Parts were cut in Netfabb for printing ease. Just rotate in RepetierHost or Pronterface for best results. I haven't printed it yet, but I recommend splitting it more in Netfabb if your printer isn't very accurate. The parts also lend themselves nicely to be mixed and matched with other lightsaber designs.
The idea behind this design was to play around and experiment for the first time in Tinkercad, and create a lightsaber hilt "shell", into which anyone could add batteries, an LED, and a real color crystal in the chamber, through which the light could pass into an acrylic rod for the beam, thus making for an as-true-to-lore lightsaber as possible. I only wish I could print it in metal.

author: RichardPB

title: Samsung S6 mount for a 1999 Mercedes Benz SLK 230

description.text: A simple Samsung S6 mount for a 1999 Mercedes Benz SLK 230. It fits into the center of the Mercedes' slide out cup holder. When not in use, the cup holder can be closed with the mount installed. There was no attempt to include a USB cable/charger.  The mount's slot is sized for a Samsung S6 in a small/thin case, but should also work with no case (as it also securely holds my Samsung S5 without a case).  I would guess it will fit in other Mercedes Benz, but don't have access to others to test it out. It fits in the SLK left to right nice, but there is an overlap in the SLK's cutout that I didn't account for, so it could be longer for a tighter fit.  I intend to use sticky tape to hold it in place, so the extra length isn't important to me.

Printer:

da vinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal
